Lubbock]] |successor= [[Andrew Jackson Hamilton]] |order2=6th |birth_date= {{birth-date|1826}} |birth_place= [[Alabama]] |death_date = August 4, {{death year and age|1865|1826}} |death_place= [[Monterrey|Monterrey, Mexico]] |residence= |alma_mater= |spouse= |profession= [[Politician]] |party= [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] |religion= }} '''Pendleton Murrah''' (1826–August 4, 1865) was the [[List of Governors of Texas|tenth Governor]] of [[Texas]]. His term in office coincided with the [[American Civil War]]. ==Career== A native of [[South Carolina]], Murrah graduated from [[Brown University]] in 1848. He moved to Texas and opened a law practice in [[Marshall, Texas|Marshall]]. He ran and was defeated for the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] before winning the state gubernatorial race in 1863. During the [[American Civil War]], Murrah emphatically supported the Rebel cause, although he ended up in a controversy over the [[conscription]] of Texas militia troops into the Confederate army. Still, even after [[Robert E. Lee]] surrendered in 1865, he encouraged Texans to continue the revolution. Only when Union occupation forces were en route to Texas did Murrah flee with other Confederate leaders to Mexico. Lt. Governor [[Fletcher Summerfield Stockdale|Stockdale]] filled the vacant post, acting as governor for three months, until provisional governor [[Andrew J. Hamilton]] assumed office in August 1865.<ref>"STOCKDALE, FLETCHER SUMMERFIELD," Handbook of Texas Online [http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fst60], accessed May 19, 2012. Published by the Texas State Historical Association.</ref> The trip was too much for his already fragile health, and in August 1865, he died in [[Monterrey|Monterrey, Mexico]] of [[tuberculosis]]. His grave is located in the Panteon Municipal of Monterrey, Mexico. ==Ancestry== Murrah was born in Bibb County, Alabama in 1826 the illegitimate son of Peggy Murrah, a daughter of Charles and Avarilla Jones Murrah. Charles, born in 1775 in Warren Co., North Carolina, traces his ancestry to Lodowick and Mira Ann Jeter Murrah of Caroline County, Virginia through their son also named Charles and his wife Margaret (Peggy). ==See also== {{Portal|Texas|American Civil War|Biography}} * [[Confederate States of America#"Died of states' rights"|"Died of states' rights" at the article Confederate States of America]] ==External links== *{{Handbook of Texas|id=fmu15|name=Pendleton Murrah}} * [http://texashistory.unt.edu/permalink/meta-pth-5827:34 Entry about Pendleton Murrah] from the [http://texashistory.unt.edu/permalink/meta-pth-5827 ''Biographical Encyclopedia of Texas''] published 1880, hosted by the [http://texashistory.unt.edu/ Portal to Texas History.] ==References== <references /> {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |title=[[List of Governors of Texas|Governor of Texas]] | before=[[Francis Lubbock]] | after=[[Andrew Jackson Hamilton|Andrew J.
